comments.commentBody: All politics are local! If you want her in the Senate and are not from Massachusetts, please donate generously and later make calls from home. She is going to need our hands on help, not just comments and FB postings.

Warren would be perfect is she also was as concerned with protecting the consumer from our Government.  Who fights for us when we see countless federal surcharges, fees and taxes added to our phone, cable, gas, electric and cellular bills.  LOOK AT YOUR BILLS PEOPLE.  Paaleese give me a break.  Another Harvard "braintrust" that wants to preach from the ivory towers on how evil profit (that fuels the economy)is. I am all for consumer protections, but those protections just cost 40,000 bank employees their jobs.

#32 Paul, #17 Watermoon:
I know someone who lives on about $3,000 per year. This puts her on a par with someone in a Third World country living in a grass hut on a muddy riverbank with raw sewage running in the street, no toilet, no electricity, cooking and eating out of the same pot, let alone getting medical and mental health care.
I truly hope Watermoon is being sarcastic.

That's it, I'm declaring Generation warfare.

As a member of Generation Y, who came of age in this "lost decade"--I graduated high school in 2003, college in December of 2007, attempted to join the workforce in the spring of 2008 and finally did the following October--I would like to graciously thank a previous generation, my parents' generation, the Baby Boomers, for handing us this mess.

What your parents, the Greatest Generation, handed off to you, you could not hand off to us. Perhaps you weren't able to, perhaps greed got the best of you, or maybe you just didn't care, but whatever the reason, you have screwed us over.

Granted, the 90's were good, although we were really too young to benefit. Generation X'ers, you got lucky, you were able to enjoy some of that decade. But aside from that, you Baby Boomers have pretty much destroyed everything else. The economy and the job market are in shambles, the environment has been forgotten, and the education system is spiraling out of control (I can't even imagine eventually sending my own kids to college with the way current tuition costs). A financial system where corrupt and immoral practices are the norm, a vanishing middle class, a social security system that is entirely unsustainable and will be depleted by the time we're 65, and a worldwide image of America that is in the toilet.

Unions are being systematically broken apart, pension funds are being sucked dry right out from under people, the U.S. infrastructure is decaying and crumbling, and an entertainment/news cycle built on instilling fear and hysteria into the masses has turned us into a nation of xenophobes. Politics has gone from being an occupation for the noble and the inspirational to an occupation for crooks, thieves, grown men and women who do nothing but throw temper-tantrums, and people who care only about themselves and their next election.

Baby Boomers, I thank you for the absolute garbage dump of a legacy you are leaving for us.

It is interesting that this piece makes no mention of the Israeli occupation, the lack of equality of Israeli Arabs with their Jewish compatriots, nor the continuing prejudice shown against the Bedouin. While it is currently quite fashionable to paint those who don't care for Israel's behavior as anti-Semitic, and to call Jewish peace advocates "self-hating," the reality--which most of the world can clearly see--is that it is Israel's behavior which has led to the world being allied against it.

There is probably no other fact more damning than seeing Avigdor Lieberman, a flat-earth advocate of continuing occupation and colonization, as Natanyahu's Foreign Minister. Much--not all--of Israel's isolation and difficulty gaining respect from the world is caused by its own behavior. Israelis need to look at South Africa's history if they want to see where their current behavior will lead them.

The moment mainstream Palestinian political reality transforms itself from revolutionary or Islamic resistance movements into a demonstrable non-violent desire for co-existance, supported by the masses, and willing to explicitly and not just tactically work for a co-operative two-state solution, is the moment the peace movement in Israel will regain traction amongst Jewish voters and drive both sides into a viable compromise agreement.

Israel will never be better off accepting a neighbor state dedicated to its eradication. Until Palistinians accept in writing that Israel has a right to exist, statehood for them is out.
Bart

The current Israeli coalition government is simply not interested in any kind of agreement with the Palestinians. The recent huge protests for affordable housing had the effect of expanding the building of more apartment for ultra orthodox settlers.
There is an economic boom in Israel and the moderate, educated and well-to-do middle-class is busy making money and planning the next vacation abroad. Secular, enlightened political parties like Shinui and Meretz have vanished or melted down.
The notion that on that "there is nobody on Arab side to talk to" is a self-defeating tactical attitude. When Israel was in danger in the past, its competent leaders made bold, justified, logical and decidedly unilateral moves.

khouri has it right.  An unbalanced solution will never be stable.  We can get it right now, or we can get it right later,  but until we do find the balance point, it will continue to be a trouble spot.

So the Census tell us that the glorious Bush decade of humongous tax breaks to JOB CREATORS, not only yielded 8M lost jobs, also gave us DOUBLE the number of poor Americans?  Giving to Caesar what belongs to Caesar,  the last year increase in poverty is due to bland Barak Obama and his coward democrats, afraid of losing their jobs as ever before, gave away to the then Republican minority and accepted extension of the tax rip-off break to the infamous “ job creators.”

< All we can do, according to this view — one that is shared by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu — is to go on living by the sword while trying to reach limited and partial solutions to contain the situation and gain time. >

Netanyahu. Lieberman, Yishai, Shalom and Co are to rather be expected to stumble and fall onto the sword ... This happened every time they got a sword.
To be clear: The Palestinians hadn't to do much more than give them a sword and wait until they stab themselves ...

Bergman, what "senses" would the international community need to come to? That scores of Palestinians don't have really clear humanitarian and societal needs that the occupation doesn't offer them? How do we get to answering that question? More of the same? How does the status quo make any sense from a Palestinian perspective?

Two states for two people is absolutely the right thing to do.
The US veto will go down in history as an act of bigotry.

At least America has pulled back from the reckless, feckless adventurism that ensnared us in land wars in Asia. We should declare victory and rebuild America's infrastructure with the money being wasted in Iraq and Afghanistan. Democracy and empire are incompatible!

Honestly, for excellent travel advice, frugal and still rich, Rick Steve's has the best website (free) and books. His research directed me very efficiently to getting excellent prices in flights, rail travel, rental cars and lodging in much of Europe. Additionally, his research and commentary on the history, culture, and sights helps me prioritize. Being an artistic type, I really enjoy his interpretative commentary on art and the fact that he directs you to how to find out what's on in various cities.

I'm finding the NYT Frugal Traveler trips poorly researched and seriously lacking in the raison d'être for taking the trouble to travel. Art, music, history, culture, struggling with the languages, connecting with real people... I guess we all have our own priorities.

I have taken Xanax off and on for years, and I've never gotten addicted or had to wean off it or had a crazy episode on it because I didn't have it.
If you read the manufacturer literature, Xanax has a "mild" anti-depressant effect, as well. I'm not sure about how "mild" that is, because it helps my anti-depressants work better. It augments them. It is also used in cancer patients to augment their pain regimens because it improves the effectiveness of pain medications, which can be crucial to a cancer patient as their pain becomes difficult to manage.

I've taken other anxiolytics, and I can tell you that for me, no other beats Xanax for efficacy - in part because it is mild and relatively short-acting, meaning I don't feel dopey or have drug hang-over in the morning. This feature of X. probably accounts for the "epidemic" of addiction more than any of its other chemical properties. Those who abuse it want to stay "high" for hours at a time, so they "need" more to maintain the high. I, for one, have never gotten high from it. If I took a double dose it would simply knock me out. And I have never been addicted to it or any other substance.
My insurance won't pay for it. Medicare doesn't allow payment for it. I'm just grateful that the generic is affordable enough for me to buy it out-of-pocket, but I resent having to do so because of abusers and over-excitable decision makers. GO AFTER THE DOCTORS WHO IMPROPERLY MANAGE A DRUG, AND THE PATIENTS WHO ABUSE THEM, NOT THE REST OF US. Punishing everyone for what some do is so grade school! I thought it was stupid then, and it's even worse to do it to adults.
It's important to note that the state of Kentucky has a terrible problem with drug addiction, period.  Watch the documentary on Current TV "Oxycontin Express."
The addicts will whine, but stopping the prescription of xanax is the smartest idea yet.

Xanax is one of the most dangerous drugs on the market.

My doc prescribed a low dose to help me sleep while I was going to college and it took me MONTHS to get off the stuff.

Cutting back on the dose made me very anxious and I was forced to cut back by tiny amounts every few days to get off this hideous drug.

I can't imagine that being hooked on heroin would be any worse.

Bottom line: if a doctor offers this poison to you find another doctor.

As a clinician, experience has taught me that it is the combination of a benzodiazepine with another drug, i.e. an opiate or ETOH which leads to mortality or morbidity.  When taken as prescribed, this class of drugs is well studied and safe for patients suffering from panic and anxiety.

Twenty years ago, I was prescribed Xanax, Klonopin and Indiral for my panic attacks and sleeplessness. My symptoms of anxiety are lifelong, but I had avoided treatment for a long time. I have been through therapy and I have personally faced tolerance and dependence. However, these medications made my life bearable and I really believe these medications have significantly improved it. Some people really seem to believe that mental illness is some sort of perverted choice people make and the cure is simply to get some religion, eat well and get more exercise. I only wish that were true. Life would be much easier if it were.

Given the dangers of overdose and dependency, I most certainly understand how these doctors must feel about Xanax from their experience. However, I have to question whether they are beginning a "Grand Experiment" with this captive group of poor folk or are they basing their decision on some study in an effort to provide the best quality of care for their patients. No where in this article do I see any citations of any studies for their actions. I do have problems with the possibility that this is becoming an unfunded, unauthorized study with uncertain outcomes for those who have been given no choice.

The only way we are going to get a jobs program from this Congress is to take a leaf from the ancient Pharaohs. We could put tens of thousands back to work building monuments to Ayn Rand. That would ensure support from the GOP (Get Obama Party). Build them out of Wisconsin cheese and even the deficit darling Paul Ryan could not resist. Its obvious, whether its GOP or conservative DLC Dem, we cannot appeal to their patriotism or their humanity. But we can appeal to their sacred ideologies and self-serving principles.

We could put everyone in the country back to work if someone could just figure out how to model the expansive egos of these public servants. Probably not enough construction materials at hand to build it to life size scale. I'm sure we could pass some deregulation and allow these monuments to be build with the organic material we find in pastures. Now that would be a fitting tribute to the GOP and Dems holding back the President's jobs program.
When will these weak kneed dodo birds learn how to fight the Atwater designed Republican Lying Machine?  I fear we are abandoned.  Let's start the Orphan Party - politics for the rest of us.

Glad Obama doesnt work on wall street picking stocks for folios. He surely bombed at the solar panel company.

I didnt vote for him either and Ive been a democrat all my life.

Guess my foresight was right.

These Democrats are embarrassing to me. I have no where to hide. What a shame.
I really believe we should just hand over the country to the Republican Lords and sit back and watch another destruction of this great Land as it fades away.
